summary: This is an email from attorney Martin G. Weinberg to prosecutors regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein. It requests preservation of evidence, DNA collection from the death scene, a taint review of seized emails due to attorney-client privilege, and inquires about the government's intention to dismiss the indictment against Epstein.

persons.name: Martin G. Weinberg
persons.context: Attorney representing the interests of Jeffrey Epstein's family after his death. He sends requests to prosecutors regarding evidence preservation, DNA collection, and the dismissal of the indictment.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased defendant. The email discusses his death, the evidence from his cell, and the potential dismissal of the indictment against him.

connections.description: Weinberg is acting on behalf of Epstein's family's interests, invoking attorney-client privilege that survives death.

events.title: Epstein Found Dead in MCC Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). Ligatures and/or bed stripping were present.

events.title: Seizure at Teterboro
events.description: Law enforcement conducted a seizure operation at the Teterboro location, presumably related to the Epstein investigation.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his MCC cell on August 10, 2019, with ligatures and bed stripping present.
Attorney Martin G. Weinberg, acting for Epstein's family, requests DNA be lifted from the ligatures/bedding found in the cell.
Weinberg invokes attorney-client privilege surviving death and requests a taint review of emails seized from Teterboro on August 6 and from Epstein's NYC residence.
The email inquires if the government intends to dismiss the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein.
